When the interest is compounded semi-annually, the effective interest rate is higher than the nominal interest rate. The difference between the two is the compounding effect.

The formula to calculate the effective interest rate is:

Effective interest rate = (1 + (Nominal interest rate / Number of times interest is compounded per year))^(Number of times interest is compounded per year) - 1

In this case, the nominal interest rate is 8%, and the interest is compounded semi-annually (twice a year).

Effective interest rate = (1 + (8%/2))^(2) - 1 â‰ˆ 8.16%

So, the actual interest rate is 8.16%, which is 0.16% higher than the nominal interest rate.
